author: funnygiulio
content: curiosity: right now on the network we have 64 committees each consisted of 526 validator. this means that we are aggregating (supposedly) 33664 attestations per slot. correct? if so why not bump down epoch duration to `8` slots? is it the computation or is there something else i am missing? for that specific epoch with an `8` slots duration you would get `33664*8=269312` which is almost half the current active validator set length

author: ralexstokes
content:
64 committees per slot, and yes each committee has something like 526 validators

so then 33664 attestations/slot

author: ralexstokes
content: if epochs were shorter, we would have even more attestations/slot to aggregate

author: ralexstokes
content: which is in general one of the more expensive computations we have in the CL

author: ralexstokes
content: there's also the trade-off b/t per-slot, per-block, and per-epoch scope processing nodes have to do; if epochs are shorter you get less amortization

author: ralexstokes
content:
> for that specific epoch with an 8 slots duration you would get 33664*8=269312 which is almost half the current active validator set length 
i think you are starting at the other end of the design space here -- we want the invariant that every validator makes 1 attestation per epoch; otherwise you start getting much more complicated analyses around finality/PoS security

author: ralexstokes
content: which at best is harder to secure, and at worst means we open ourselves up to attacks on finality

author: funnygiulio
content: oooh ok i see, yes thanks for clarifying that. but then what about 16 slots per epoch? all validators would attest during that epoch. mh I immagine that the 32 slots per epoch is to be safe everyone attests once per epoch at least then

author: funnygiulio
content: fix on my statement: there are actually 1m validators active so yeah i think that answers my own question
